body_text.text: The site was originally discovered in the late 1930's (Holden, 1974) . Since then, work has been done by four separate archaeological projects in and around the site, including the current Lubbock Lake Project. However, until the present investigations began only Sellards (1952) and Green (1962) had published on their previous work. The earlier paper dealt only with the Folsom material while the latter work was a very general treatment aimed at the general public. The Lubbock Lake Project is a research program being carried out under the auspices of The Museum of Texas Tech University and supported by the National Science Foundation, Texas Historical Commission, and the City and County of Lubbock. One of the first goals of the project was to bring together as much information as possible concerning the earlier work at the site and correlate this information with the work done during the first field season of the project. These goals were attained and the correlations were published in a symposium volume edited by Black (1974) .

The Lubbock Lake Project is multidisciplinary in nature and focuses on man's adaptation to ecological change on the Llano Estacado and the nature of these changes over the past 12,000 years. One of the primary requirements for an examination of man's past throughout time is the establishment of a chronological framework for a region.

The necessity of this framework for the Llano Estacado has been recognized by Collins (1971) , Hughes (1976) and Kelley (1964) . Local chronolgoies must be established as a part of such a regional chronology.
At the Lubbock Lake site, the past and current excavations have been relatively limited compared to the total area of the locality.

The area fenced off by the City of Lubbock and generally believed to be the site itself occupies about 20 acres. During the course of the work of the Lubbock Lake Project it has been determined, however, that the Lubbock Lake site covers at least 110 acres on the surface and is generally at least 20 feet deep ( Fig. 1 ). Of this acreage, all of the excavations since the late 1930's and through the summer of 1976 have removed less than 1%, in volume, of the site. In addition, the emphasis of the investigations has been on the earlier levels (Paleoindian deposits), although the more recent deposits have received some study. Nevertheless, the detailed archaeological and geological investigations of the Lubbock Lake Project and the radiocarbon sequence that is beginning to develop, combined with data recovered by previous investigators, provide the basic information necessary for the establishment of a cultural chronology, however preliminary, for the Lubbock area. As a frame of reference, the previous investigations at the Lubbock Lake site and pertinent archaeological work on the Llano Estacado are summarized and the nature and scope of the Lubbock Lake Project presented. The chronology, in its present form, is described. This presentation includes a discussion of the lithic artifact inventory, the regional relationships of the diagnostic artifacts, and specific chronological information provided by radiocarbon determinations. The concluding statements are a discussion of the major chronological problems and possible solutions.
The Lubbock Lake Site
In the middle 1930's, the City of Lubbock, in cooperation with the Works Progress Administration, decided to excavate a reservoir for the purpose of containing water for emergency fire fighting.
The area selected was a meander bend of Yellowhouse Draw, to the northwest of the city. After the dredging operations, several

Paleoindian artifacts and remains of extinct fauna were found on the dikes created around the reservoir from dump material. In 1939, the W.P.A., in cooperation with the then West Texas Museum, funded excavations at the site as a part of a larger scale archaeological project in the area (Green, 1962; Holden, 1962 Holden, , 1974 Wheat, 1974) .

The first archaeological excavations at the Lubbock Lake site were directed by Wheat (1974) in 1939 and 1941 . Most of the work was conducted in the upper deposits due to the high water table at the time. However, one long trench was excavated (Trench A), extending to the southwest of the reservoir and continuing to the edge of the valley fill (Fig. 2) . Excavations reached the Archaic deposits but not the strata bearing extinct fauna. The results of this work were summarized in a W.P.A. report (Wheat, 1939) and more recently by Wheat (1974) . Kelley (1974) This work continued in 1948 work continued in , 1950 work continued in , and 1951 work continued in (Holden, 1974 Kelley, 1974; Sellards, 1952) . The field work was conducted by Grayson Meade and Glen L. Evans, Five strata were identified. Most of the work consisted of cleaning the walls of the reservoir cut with more intensive investigations conducted at various "stations" along the walls (Fig. 2) . Almost all of the work was concentrated in the Paleoindian deposits. Among other discoveries, several Folsom points were found in association with extinct bison (Bison antiquus). A unifacial composite tool was found in a fluvial sand unit below the Folsom level. Mammoth (Elaphas cf. columbi) remains were also recovered in the sands but the association of the mammoth and the tool is uncertain. One of the most significant results of the work of the Texas Memorial Museum and a landmark in early man studies in North America was the determination of the first radiocarbon date for the Folsom period. The date was computed by Willard Libby (1955) in 1950 from charred bison remains associated with lithic artifacts from what was believed to be a Folsom level. The resulting date was 9883 + 350 years B.P. (Sellards, 1952) . In 1955, an additional date was secured from snail shells and was calculated at 9700 + 450 years B.P. (Broecker and Kulp, 1957) , The work of the Texas Memorial Museum was briefly reported by Sellards (1952) and a description of the artifacts given by Kelley (1974) . The accession records and various field notes and drawings are on file at the Texas Archeological Research Laboratory, The University of Texas, Austin.
Most of the artifacts recovered are also stored there.

The last major archaeological work at the Lubbock Lake site before the current project began was carried out by the then West Texas Museum (now The Museum of Texas Tech University) under the direction of F. E. Green and Jane Holden Kelley. Most of their work was concentrated on the west side of the site (Fig. 2) in the upper strata. Some work was conducted in the deeper deposits, including the Paleoindian ones. Green, (1962) recognized seven geological strata in this area. The results of this work were summarized by Green (1962) and Kelley (1974) . Artifacts recovered during this work and the accession information are housed at The Museum of Texas Tech University.

Although Wheat's (1974) excavations and a major part of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) work was in the post-Paleoindian deposits, the Lubbock Lake site has been known principally as a Paleoindian site. This is probably a result of several factors, including: 1) Sellards ' (1952) discussion of the site which referred only to the Paleoindian occupation; 2) the publicity involved in the first radiocarbon date secured for the Folsom culture; and 3) the lack of information available for the non-Paleoindian strata.

Very little systematic work has been conducted in the Lubbock vicinity outside of the Lubbock Lake site area. Wheat (1955) reported work conducted by the W.P.A. at two sites in southeast Lubbock County, along Yellowhouse Canyon. This work was part of the same program in which the initial excavations at the Lubbock Lake site were conducted. The artifact inventories from these sites indicated that both were either of very late prehistoric or historic age. In the same area, Newcomb (1958) reported an historic Indian burial found eroding out of a wall along the canyon. Recently, another burial in the same area was partially excavated by the Department of Anthropology at Texas Tech University.

County was that done along the Yellowhouse Draw drainage within the city limits of Lubbock in 1975. This reconnaissance was a part of mitigation work related to land modification activites being carried out by the City of Lubbock along the drainage. The results of the survey and preliminary testing was reported by Johnson and Stafford (1976) . A total of 16 sites were reported for the area to be affected by the construction. Machine testing was carried out at most of the sites. Hand testing was done at one of the localities, the Nash site (41LU35), situated along the draw about 1.5 miles downstream from the Lubbock Lake site. This work revealed an archaeological and geological sequence almost identical to that at the Lubbock Lake site (Johnson and Stafford, 1976) .
body_text.section: The only major systematic archaeological survey in Lubbock

body_text.text: In addition to the mitigation work for the City of Lubbock, Pioneer Natural Gas Company laid a pipeline through the area immediately north of the Lubbock Lake site during 1975. A survey was conducted along the pipeline route where it crossed public land.
body_text.section: The only major systematic archaeological survey in Lubbock

body_text.text: Four new sites were recorded. It was further determined that a portion of the Lubbock Lake site would be affected (Area 14) . The artifacts recovered from the surface reconnaissance ranged in age from late Paleoindian through Ceramic periods, None of these sites had any depth except for Area 14, 41LU1. The trench for the pipeline truncated a hearth in this area. Excavations yielded a number of lithic items, including a Garza point, in association with the hearth (Johnson and Johnson, 1975) .
body_text.section: The only major systematic archaeological survey in Lubbock

body_text.text: As a part of the 1975 excavations of the Lubbock Lake Project, some machine testing was conducted at the Spring site (41LU27) just to the northwest of the main portion of Lubbock Lake site. Although given a separate site number because of the distance from the central part of the Lubbock Lake site, the Spring site is probably a continuation of it. Little cultural material was recovered, but it was possible to correlate the stratigraphy of this old spring reentrant with the stratigraphy of the basinal section of the Lubbock Lake site (E. Johnson, 1976b) .
body_text.section: The only major systematic archaeological survey in Lubbock

body_text.text: Two general reviews of the archaeology of the Llano Estacado have been published in the past 15 years. Kelley (1962) presented a brief comprehensive review of the archaeology of the region.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Collins (1971) compiled the most recent and complete review to date.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Two studies (Wendorf, 1961; Wendorf and Hester, 1975) were published dealing with the late Quaternary paleoecology and paleoenvironments of the Southern High Plains. In addition, Wendorf (1970) published some specific paleoecological work related to these studies. Other studies of a general nature include Hughes' (1976) summary of the Panhandle Archaic; Corley's (1965) work on the Jornada Branch of the Mogollon on the Llano Estacado; Honea's (1973) study of Puebloan pottery in the area; Dillehay's (1972) theories on bison population changes on the southern Plains; Duffield; s (1970) dissertation on the vertebrates and paleoecology of the Panhandle Aspect along the Canadian River; and Pearson's (1974) study of soils and archaeological sites in Palo Duro Canyon.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: In terms of investigations of individual sites, the most well known localities are the early man sites. As previously mentioned, the Lubbock Lake site was known as a Paleoindian locality. Other Paleoindian localities include: Blackwater Draw, Locality #1 (Hester, 1972) ; Plainview (Sellards, et al., 1947) : Lipscomb (Schultz, 1943) ;
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Miami (Sellards, 1938) ; San Jon (Roberts, 1942) ; Elida (Hester, 1962; Warnica, 1961) ; Milnesand (Sellards, 1955; Warnica and Williamson, 1968) ; Scharbauer (Midland) (Wendorf, et al., 1955) ; McLean (Ray, 1942) ; Lone Wolf Creek (Cook, 1927; Figgins, 1927) ; Rex Rogers (Speer, 1975) ; and Lake Theo (Harrison and Smith, 1975) (Fig. 3 ). Of these sites, Blackwater Draw, Locality #1 (Hester, 1972) is one of the most well known archaeological sites in North America. Similar to the Lubbock Lake site in its stratigraphy and cultural sequence, 25 different field projects have investigated the site. A further and unfortunate similarity between the two sites is that relatively little has been published on the work. Hester (1972) attempted to synthesize all of the past work. Since the site is now virtually destroyed, little additional work can be done. However, some recent testing has taken place along the margins of the site (Agogino, et al., 1976; Stephens, 1973) . The similarities between Blackwater Draw, Locality #1 and the Lubbock Lake site makes the former one of the most important sites on the Llano Estacado in terms of work done at the Lubbock Lake site.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Investigation of Archaic sites on the Llano Estacado have been minimal. As noted by Hughes (1976) , Collins (1971) , and Kelley (1962) , few localities containing Archaic age material are known and of those reported, many are surface occurrences. Sites of Archaic age or containing Archaic components that have been tested or excavated include; Twilla (Tunnel and Hughes, 1955) ; Little Sunday (Hughes, 1955) ; Floydada Country Club (Word, 1963) ; Montgomery (Word, 1965) : Chalk Hollow (Wedel, 1975) ; and Pete Creek (Parson, 1967 . Riggs (1965 reports Archaic materials collected from the surface of "Ly-4". In addition, Collins (1966, 1968) reported Archaic material from seven of the "Andrews Lake localities"; Katz and Katz (1976) reported Archaic material from several sites in Lower Tule Canyon; and Willey and Hughes (1975) reported some Archaic material from Lake Theo State Park in Briscoe County. The Lake

body_text.text: The late prehistoric on the Llano Estacado, generally referred to as the Neo-American or Ceramic period, is best represented along the northern margin of the Llano Estacado on the Canadian River and its tributaries (Collins, 1971) . Sites in this area are from the Antelope Creek Focus of the Panhandle Aspect. More archaeological work has been carried out on this stage of aboriginal occupation of the Llano Estacado than any other period, with the exception of the Paleoindian period. Collins (1971) provided information on the work conducted in this cultural period through the time of his writing. The only published report since then is Keller's (1975) monograph. Collins (1971) also summarized two interesting problems concerning Southwestern influences on the Llano Estacado. One question involved the previously mentioned study by Corley (1965) of an eastern variety of the Jornada branch of the Mogollon. The other, more puzzling, problem was that of Plains artifacts found in association with Puebloan pottery. This phenomenon occurs at the Lubbock Lake site and will be discussed in more detail below.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: A number of late prehistoric sites apparently not related to the Antelope Creek Focus have been reported from the Llano Estacado.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: These sites include: Jim Arnold (Tunnel, 1964) ; Floydada Country Club (Word, 1963) ; Montgomery (Word, 1965) ; Garza (Runkles, 1964) ;
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Pete Creek, Grape Creek, and Dockum Springs (Parsons, 1967) ; and "A769" (Harrison and Griffin, 1973) . Other sites were reported from the Lower Tule Canyon (Katz and Katz, 1976) , the Andrews Lake area by Collins (1966 Collins ( , 1968 , and Lake Theo State Park by Willey and Hughes (1975) . Witte (1947 Witte ( , 1955 reported some pre-contact burials from Gray and Donley Counties, respectively. Pearce (1936) mentioned ceramic artifacts from Lamb and Bailey counties that were probably from the late prehistoric or contact periods ( Fig. 4 ).
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Little is known of the Historic period on the Southern High Plains. Collins (1971:90) stated that: "The Pete Creek site is the only significant occupation of this stage that has been investigated."
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: Parsons (1967) believed that Collett Springs site to be of Historic age. Several Historic burials are known. Kelley (1964) reported one from near Lamesa and another from near Stanton. The White site (Suhm, 1961) and the Morgan Jones site (Parsons, 1967) contained Historic burials. Several Historic rock art sites are known and were reported by Jackson (1938) , Newcomb and Kirkland (1967) ,
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: and Riggs (1965b Riggs ( , 1966 .

body_text.text: This brief review of previous archaeological investigations in the Lubbock area and on the Llano Estacado is an indication of the lack of archaeological work and the paucity of reports for the area.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: As a result, the overall archaeological sequence is not well known or understood. Even locally, few areas have adequate chronologies.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: In light of these problems, extensive and detailed excavations at a well-stratified locality such as the Lubbock Lake site become of greater significance. It is hoped that the chronological framework being established for the Lubbock Lake site will provide the basis for a regional chronology for the Southeastern Llano Estacado and adjacent areas of the Rolling Plains.
body_text.section: Related Studies on the Llano Estacado

body_text.text: During the summer of 1973, excavations were renewed at the Lubbock Lake site under the auspices of The Museum of Texas Tech

University. This work has continued to the present time with excavations conducted during the summers of 1973, 1974, 1975, and 1976 . The project involves the fields of archaeology, geology, and paleontology. The major goal of the project is the reconstruction of the various cultures and paleoenvironments that existed in the area for the past 12,000 years and how they relate to one another.

Field work has consisted principally of the recovery of archaeological and paleontological material. Great care is taken to recover as much information as possible during the course of the excavations. Detailed notes and records are kept on the material recovered with most specimens recorded in. situ. The basic excavation unit is 1 meter square, 5 centimeters deep. Even material not recovered ijn. situ can then be placed within a relatively small area.

All of the matrix removed from a unit is washed through graduated screens for the recovery of micro-faunal, micro-botanical, and micro-cultural remains. A total of 17 areas were investigated by the end of the 1976 field season (Fig, 5) . Emphasis has been on the Paleoindian levels, although late prehistoric and historic deposits received some study and all levels have undergone some testing.
The archaeological/paleontological excavations are only a part of the investigations being conducted by the project. Machine testing has been undertaken, principally for geological purposes.

Numerous trenches and profile cuts have been made in order to locate, identify, map, and correlate the various strata seen throughout the site. Laboratory work continues throughout the year in order to identify, catalog, preserve, and study all of the material recovered in the field. Various specific studies are being undertaken.

including paleobotanical investigations of the pollen and seeds, paleopedology, malacology, and radiocarbon dating. Essentially, the project is attempting to involve disciplines that will provide information on the past 12,000 years in the area.

For establishing a cultural chronology for the site, the most important studies, besides the analysis of the artifacts recovered, are the stratigraphic and paleopedological investigations and the radiocarbon dating. The first two analyses have resulted in a physical framework in which to examine the spacial relationships of the cultural remains in addition to providing information concerning the environmental setting. Age determinations provide a means of assigning absolute dates to the various strata and cultural features within the framework, thus providing a means of examining the temporal relationships of the cultural remains. A general description of the stratigraphy of the Lubbock Lake site follows, based principally on Stafford (1977) , building on the work of C.
Johnson (1974) , Johnson and Johnson (1976) , and E. Johnson (1976) .
A generalized geologic profile is presented in Fig. 6 . General age assessments and specific radiocarbon dates are included in the discussion of the cultural chronolgoy in the following section.

The "bedrock" in the region of the Lubbock Lake site consists of early Pleistocene (Blancan) lacustrine sediments. Generally, these are overlain by eolian deposits of probable middle Pleistocene age. The Lubbock Lake site is situated in a meander bend of Yellowhouse Draw, a drainage basin that has been incised into the early and middle Pleistocene lacustrine and eolian deposits. The incision probably took place in the middle Wisconsin. Stratum 1 of the deposits at the Lubbock Lake site consists of fluvial gravels (lA), sands (IB), and clays (IC) that rest unconformably on the incised Blancan deposits. These deposits indicate that a small river was active in the Yellowhouse drainage for some time. The age of the stream dated between 12,500 and 11,000 years B.P. Substratum 4B makes up the bulk of stratum 4 and consists of oxidized alluvial and eolian sands with some gravel deposits. A very well developed paleosol (substratum 4C) is seen at the top of 4B. This was originally believed to be the "Altithermal soil" of about 5,000 to 4,000 years B.P. (C. Johnson, 1974:97,100) . Archaeological evidence indicates that these dates may be as much as 2,000 years too old.

Stratum 5 consists of two major facies; an upland facies with two substrata (5A and 5B) and a lowland facies (substratum 5C). The upland facies appear to be a recurrence of the 4B/4C sequence of eolian and alluvial deposits capped by a soil, with each substrata consisting of an eolian/alluvial unit and a soil. Both eolian/alluvial units are much thinner than 4B and both soils are less well developed than 4C. (Wormington, 1957; Wheat, 1972) . In general, less is known about the Paleoindian period in North America than any other cultural horizon. However, due to the great amount of investigation into this period at the Lubbock Lake site, this is the best known cultural period in this area. 2) the stratigraphic position of the cultural remains below the Folsom horizon; and 3) associated radiocarbon dates that place the horizon within the time range of the Clovis period as defined by
Haynes (1970) .
No diagnostic lithic artifacts have been recovered in direct association with the extinct fauna. However, as previously mentioned

Evans and Meade (Sellards, 1952) Johnson (1977:58) believes that these may be pounding stones, especially TTU-A16407. Also, several large caliche boulders were found among the bones that may have been used as anvils (Johnson, 1976a: 136-137).

The Lubbock Lake Project has secured two radiocarbon dates on (Haynes, 1970) . The clam shell date is slightly older than that normally expected for the Clovis period. However, this may be due to the nature of the dated material (Herbert Haas, personal communication).
substratum

The next cultural horizon within the Paleoindian deposits at the Lubbock Lake site is the Folsom period. Evidence of a Folsom occupation is seen in the laminated diatomite (Substratum 2A). This horizon is identified on the basis of the recovery of the distinctive Folsom type projectile point. Occupation seems to be confined to one or two organic layers (cienegas) seen between some of the pure diatomite laminations. The Lubbock Lake site is probably best known as a Folsom locality, the site having been identified as such by Sellards (1952) and Wormington (1957) . 3 is between the two areas where four Folsom points were found in situ by the Texas Memorial Museum. This lens may well be the one from which the Folsom points came, and may be the same as or perhaps stratigraphically above the lens in which FA6-8 is located. The three dates provide a bracket for the age of FA6-8 which is in line with Wheat's (1972:156-157) range of dates for the Folsom horizon.

In considering the two dates from the Folsom horizon secured in the 1950's, Johnson (1974:91) felt that due to the nature of the material dated (bone and shell), the dates may be as much as 1,000 years too young. However, it is possible that the bone bed from which the dates were secured may not have been the result of a Folsom occupation. The Lubbock Lake Project excavators have done some testing in the area from which the dated bone came (Evans and Meade's station M, Fig. 2 ) and encountered what is probably a part of the same bone bed (FA5-5). The substratum in which this feature was found is 2B, the diatomaceous earth, and not 2A, the diatomite (E. Johnson, 1976a:132) . This would suggest that the feature is of the late Paleoindian age (Plainview?) rather than Folsom age.
Little is known concerning the Folsom occupation in the area.

Only kill/butchering locales have been found. As the kills involved only a few individual bison rather than large-scale drives or traps, it may be speculated that small groups, perhaps only a few families,

were inhabiting the area. Agate Basin. There are many other types of points assigned to this time period. One of the greatest problems in dealing with this time period is the projectile point typology and nomenclature. Many "types" are probably variations or modifications of other types. An excellent example of this was Wheat's (1976) recent determination that San Jon points, a long standing type, are simply reworked Firstview points. Both Wheat (1972, 1976) and Wormington (1957) have discussed the problems of late Paleoindian projectile point typology. Wheat's (1972) study of the taxonomy of points from the Olsen-Chubbock site is a fine history of the classification of some of the late Paleoindian points. In addition, this discussion placed the problem in perspective and eliminated some of the confusion.
Wheat's (1976) analysis of Firstview and San Jon points is a continuation of the typological study of the Olsen-Chubbock material.
Wheat (1972, 1976) and Wormington (1957) are the principal authorities for the typology of the late Paleoindian materials recovered at the Lubbock Lake site.

A total of five late Paleoindian projectile points and fragments have been found rn situ at the Lubbock Lake site. In addition, four artifacts that could be considered to be late Paleoindian points were found on the dredge piles in 1938 along with the two Folsom points previously mentioned. During the work of the Texas Memorial Museum, two projectile points, similar to late Paleoindian varieties, were found on the surface. A "Portales-like" point was found, apparently in situ near station A (Fig. 2) , by a visitor to the site in 1949 (Kelley, 1974:52) . There has been some discussion concerning whether or not the matrix in which the point was located was original or had slumped down the face of the wall (Kelley, 1974:52) .
During Green's (1962) excavation, a reworked point was found in what is now termed substratum 2C in the southwest portion of the reservoir cut. The Lubbock Lake Project has found parts of three late
Paleoindian projectile points in situ and one point, possibly of this period, redeposited in a more recent substratum.

The "Portales-like" projectile point Fig. 8, b) found in 1949 is the only complete late Paleoindian projectile point thus far discovered at the Lubbock Lake site. Unfortunately, the present location of this specimen is not known as it was returned to the collector. A plaster cast was made, but all that remains is the tip which is quite worn. One photograph ( Fig. 8 ) and a set of line drawings were also made. All of these items are stored at the Texas Archeological Research Laboratory (TARL). Originally described as a "Portales-like" point, Kelley (1974:52) referred to the artifact as a Plainview point. As Wheat (1972:153) noted, the Portales complex as defined by Sellards (1952:72-74) is rather anomalous, containing a variety of distinctly different projectile point forms (including Plainview, Firstview, Agate Basin, and the nowdefunct San Jon). To term a point "Portales-like" is to say nothing more than that it is similar to these point types, the principal attributes being a lanceolate outline and a lenticular to diamond shaped cross section. Based on the published drawing (Kelley, 1974: 54), the point (TMM 892-69) resembles a Plainview, with parallel sides, a concave base, and basically irregular flaking. A comparison of this drawing with the existing photograph and drawings on file at TARL reveals, however, that the published drawing is inaccurate. The point definitely has a straight base and exhibits finer flaking. The point seems to conform to Wheat's (1972) Firstview variety, at least in outline. The cast that remains has a lenticular cross section and apparently a rounded medial ridge as does Firstview. The flaking does not appear to be as fine as most of the Firstview points from the Olsen-Chubbock site (Wheat, 1972) . However, in discussing the "Portales complex" material of Sellards (1952) , Wheat (1972:146-147 ) assigned a number of these points to the Firstview variety. One of the points (Sellards, 1952:73, Fig. 37d that described by Wheat (1976) for points being reused as butchering tools.

Artifact TTU-A8642 ( Fig. 9, h ) was apparently geologically redeposited in substratum 5C. It was recovered in Area 9 ( (Sellards, 1952; Wheat, 1974) . The expanding stem and concave base suggest, however, some of the Plainview varieties such as that illustrated by Sellards, et al. (1947: 960, Plate 5, Fig. 1 ) or the Plainview-Golondrina variety of L. Johnson (1964:46-52) .
The surface finds, in some ways, present an even more difficult problem in typology. These items can be considered as Paleoindian (Kelley, 1974:52 ).

Kelley (1974:52) however, reported that Sellards and Evans felt that perhaps the entire face of the wall in this area had slumped and perhaps the point was from "stratum 3" (substratum 2C of the Lubbock Lake Project). Stratigraphic work by the Lubbock Lake Project in Area 9 demonstrated that the stratum 2 deposit in this area consisted totally of the "marginal valley facies" (Stafford, 1977) . The unit ^ X has been designated substratum 2E and is probably a near-shore facies >;

of the diatomaceous earth (substratum 2B). It is unconformably overlain by substratum 5C (the "muck layer" Green's (1962) work is j described as coming from the "cienega" or substratum 2C. (Wheat, 1972:157) . A date of 9,961 + 79 years B.P. (SMU 275) was secured from the base of substratum 2B in another excavation area (Area 2). A radiocarbon sample from the Plainview occupation in Area 6 is now being run. The information from Area 6 further suggests that a possible Firstview occupation is concentrated near the top of substratum 2B. Dates of 7,967 + 80 years B.P. (SMU 262) and 8,119 + 117 years B.P. Both of these sites represent mass kills.

Little else, then, is known concerning the Plainview occupation of the southern Plains. At the Lubbock Lake site, the area was used as a hunting and butchering locality. has been seen on the Llano Estacado (Wheat, 1972:152, 154, 157-158) .
The Archaic period at the Lubbock Lake site, as on the Llano Estacado, is poorly represented. Wheat's (1974) Stratigraphically, the Archaic probably involves strata 3 and 4.

However, no diagnostic artifacts of any kind and very little cultural material of any kind have come from stratum 3. The assignment of this unit to the Archaic is thus very tentative. The principal rationale for this is based on dating the underlying substratum 2C.

Radiocarbon dates indicated that the development of the "cienega" terminated between 8,000 and 7,500 years ago. This period is the approximate time for the termination of the Paleoindian occupation on the southern Plains (Wheat, 1972:157-158) . Stratum 3, then, may represent the early Archaic. Both strata 3 and 4 have evidence of some sort of soil development (substrata 3C, 4C, and possibly 4A).

Archaeological and some preliminary radiocarbon evidence suggests that the time represented by the two strata ranges from about 7,500 to 1,000 years ago. This comprises essentially the entire Archaic and the early Ceramic periods. However, the degree of development of the soils demands that in order that pedogenesis could take place much if not most of this period was one of landscape stability (little deposition and erosion). Some deposition did occur. Stratum 4 is as much as 3 to 4 meters thick on the west side of the site.
The implications are that the Archaic period was one of rapid and at times, relatively massive deposition (both eolian and alluvial)

followed by long periods of surface stability (the soil forming intervals). Archaeologically, this resulted in long periods of occupation represented by relatively thin strata. Green (1962:118) apparently encountered an occupation near the base of substratum 4C
in his excavations on the west side of the site (Fig. 2) . Although his excavations continued through the upper portions of stratum 2, little other occupational evidence was encountered.
The available archaeological evidence for an Archaic occupation is extremely meager. The evidence comes principally from Wheat's (1939; 1974) excavations in substratum 4C and the upper part of 4B.

The artifacts recovered were illustrated by Wheat (1974) . These jj excavations recovered the base of a projectile point (TTU 40-36-6) similar to the Bulverde variety (Suhm and Jelks, 1962:169-170) , more common to the south and east of the Llano Estacado. The specimen was battered and apparently reworked. This artifact came from the upper sand deposits of substratum 4B in his Trench A (west), just below the A soil horizon (4C). A complete point (TTU 40-36-5) similar to the Ellis variety (Suhm and Jelks, 1962:187-188) was found in the backdirt of Trench A (west) (Fig. 2) . Wheat (1974:30) felt relatively certain about the stratigraphic sequence, identifying the original location as the lower portion of substratum 4C. Two projectile points resembling the Trinity type (Suhm and Jelks, 1962:253-254) were also recovered, one (TTU 40-36-56) in situ from Trench A (west) and the other in the backdirt pile (TTU 40-36-10). Wheat (1974:30) believed that the specimen found in the backdirt pile came from the lower portion of substratum 4C as did the in situ artifact. middle Archaic in age and dating from 5,000 to 4,000 years ago (Sorrow, et al., 1967:142-147; Weir, 1976:63-64) . The Trinity type, more common to East and Southwest Texas is dated between 4,000 and 3,000 years ago by Suhm and Jelks (1962:253) but older than 6,000 years ago by McCormick (1976:44) . Evidence at the Lubbock Lake site would indicate that the younger dates are more acceptable.

The Ellis variety is apparently common throughout Texas but seems to be more frequently found in East Texas. Suhm and Jelks (1962:187) date this type between 3,000 and 1,000 years ago. This is in line with the evidence at the Lubbock Lake site, although McCormick (1976:44) believes the type to be from 5,000 to 4,000 years old.

These points and dates indicate, then, the presence of a middle to H rni late Archaic occupations in the area. Occupation of the area apparently occurred throughout the Archaic period.

Such limited archaeological evidence, of course, gives almost no insight into Archaic lifeways. The meager evidence recovered during the various excavations suggests that perhaps there was limited occupation of the area during the Archaic period. Green (1962: 117-118) also suggested this theory. He believed substratum 4B

(his Stratum 4) to be eolian material and felt that this was evidence of a hot, dry, inhospitable climate correlateable to Antevs (1948; 1955) Altithermal interval (Green, 1962:117) . C. Johnson (1974:95-97) also felt that substratum 4B was essentially eolian and correlated this unit with the Altithermal interval. However, he was more cautious about the climatic implications of the deposit and felt that, for the present, the time-stratigraphic significance of substrata 4B and the 4C soil should be of more concern (C. Johnson, 1974:97) .

Stafford (1977) of archaeological remains from substratum 4C, which represents a stable surface exposed for at least several thousand years. The archaeological evidence now suggests that this soil dates from about Green (1962) and Johnson (1974) . The Medithermal, which followed the Altithermal, was postulated as being basically the modern climate (Antevs, 1948; 1955) . If so, this climate would certainly be more inviting to prospective inhabitants that the climate hypothesized for the Altithermal. In this case, the lack of archaeological remains in the sbustratum 4C soil is all the more puzzling. Additional paleoenvironmental as well as archaeological work needs to be undertaken in the entire stratum 3 and 4 sequence in order to determine the nature of the cultural and environmental seuqence during the Archaec period.

The last prehistoric period seen at the Lubbock Lake site reresents that time from when ceramic technology first appeared in the archaeological record through the time of the appearance of the first Europeans on the Llano Estacado in A.D. 1541. Evidence for this period is somewhat more common than that for the Archaic period.

Little in the way of diagnostic cultural material has been recovered from excavations in the Ceramic period. The Chupadero Black-on-White sherds recovered by Wheat (1974) and the Scallorn and Perdiz material reported by Kelley (1974) , are the only timediagnostic indicators. The significance of Lott points in unknown. This designation is | an informal term for a variety of points common to the southern Llano I Estacado. The type has yet to be formally described and specific associations and distribution are not known.

Considering the limited excavations in the Historic period at the Lubbock Lake site, indications are that the area was heavily occupied during this period. Hearths and associated occupational debris indicate a number of camping areas. In addition, economic pursuits are seen in the one kill/butchering locale and the several processing
stations. ^ CHAPTER V

The Lubbock Lake site has undergone investigation by the crews of four different projects. The first three endeavors recovered significant information, although relatively little of the work has been published. The current investigations (Lubbock Lake Project) consist of an interdisciplinary program studying the archaeology, geology, and paleontology of the locality. By means of the stratigraphic and radiocarbon information that has resulted from this project, it has been possible to construct a physical framework in which to examine both the spatial and temporal relationships of the archaeological material recovered. This has resulted in the establishment of a preliminary cultural chronology for the Lubbock Lake site.
Four basic cultural periods have been identified along with vari-rn{ X ous subperiods. These periods are:
"• 'j i

1) Paleoindian -12,000 to 8,000 years B.P. Various Essentially, in order to recover cultural remains, intensive work in the Archaic age deposits, especially the buried soil horizons, is necessary. Additional paleoenvironment information is needed in order to determine the nature and extent of the "Altithermal" in this area and its possible effects on the inhabitants of the region.

For the Ceramic period, again, the recovery of additional cultural material is necessary. Both Wheat's (1974) and Green's (1962) work indicates that the material is present, apparently in some quan- In this section is presented an inventory of the stone tools thus far recovered by the Lubbock Lake Project. A variety of lithic material is represented in the artifact collection from the Lubbock Lake site. In the Lubbock area there are no major naturally occuring outcrops of good raw material for the manufacture of lithic tools.

Rather there are a number of sources both near and far from which some raw material of varying type and quality can be procured. These Other lithic materials include chalcedony, usually a very finegrained, milky, sometimes translucent white. Similar in appearance to the chalcedony is an opalized caliche, again fine-grained and a translucent or milky white. The sources or formations from which these materials come is, as yet, unknown (Michael J. Kaczor, personal communication) . Some petrified wood has also been found, probably from Triassic outcrops (John P. Brand, personal communication).

FIGREF0.text: reviewed some of the artifactual remains recovered by Wheat. Most of the artifacts recovered and some accession information are housed at The Museum of Texas Tech University. By 1948, the water table in the Lubbock area had dropped appreciably due to increased irrigation on the Llano Estacado. At the Lubbock Lake site, the reservoir cut was completely dry and the entire stratigraphic sequence of the locality was exposed along the walls. At this time E. H. Sellards, Director of the Texas Memorial Museum, became interested in the site and began excavations in 1948.

FIGREF1.text: recovered a unifacial tool iri situ in what was apparently substratum IB on the west side of the site. Furthermore, a portion of another unifacial tool (TTU-A7906,Fig. 14,e) was found by the Lubbock Lake Project personnel in backdirt from machine testing near Area 6. The matrix on this item appeared to be the IB sands. The principal Clovis period feature being excavated by the Lubbock Lake Project is FA2-1 (i.e. Feature 1 in Area 2). This feature has been identified byJohnson (1976) as a processing station. This is a locality where animal remains were further processed after the kill and initial butchering. This situation is evidenced by scattered elements and a high degree of bone breakage for marrow extraction and tool manufacturing. The mammoth remains best exhibt this evidence and because of the size of this animal, the kill area was probably nearby. Few lithic items of any sort have been found in association with this feature. However, several cobbles (TTU-A16407, TTU-A16960, and TTU-A16999) were found in association with the bone. Two of the cobbles (TTU-A16960 and TTU-A16999) are of quartzite, a material not common in any of the stratum 1 deposits. The third cobble (TTU-A16407) is made of indurated caliche and exhibits some battering along one side. The feature is in the substratum IB sands and cobbles of any sort are rare.

FIGREF2.text: total of 10 Folsom points or fragments of points have been recovered from the Lubbock Lake site. Two of the points Fig. 7; Fig. 8,c)  were found on the fresh dump piles shortly after the original dredging of the site. The discovery of these two points, in part, brought scientific attention to the importance and potential of the site in the late 1930's. During the course of the excavations by the Texas Memorial Museum, near stations I and D (Fig. 1), four Folsom points 71, 77, Figs. 9,f, b,, missing from the collections) were found in situ in the lower diatomite, and associated with extinct bison (Bison antiquus). In addition, two more points4, Figs. 9, e, c)    were found in the dredge material. In 1954, another Folsom point (TTU-55-27,Fig. 9, a) was found in situ by a Boy Scout and examined by staff members of the West Texas Museum before it was removed(Kelley, 1974:50-51). One other Folsom point is known to have been recovered by a local collector from the dredge material. The points recovered in situ were found along the east and southeast wall of the site. The two surface finds made at this time were from the south side of the site. The association of the ±n_ situ artifacts (Texas Memorial Museum work) with extinct bison is clearly documented. Nevertheless, little in known concerning the nature of the bone beds per se. Parts of a bone bed in the lower diatomite are visible in this area of the site. However, beyond very limited testing, the current project has not investigated this feature. Work has been conducted, however, in what is believed to be Folsom occupational layers in Area 5 and 6, on the west side of the site(Fig. 5). In Area 6, a large feature (FA6-8) has been exposed what represents a kill/butchering locale(Johnson, 1976:127). Butchered remains of at least two bison have been recovered. Bones of the animals were placed in distinctive piles. A number of bone tools have been identified, and a butchering tool (TTU-A 2655) and a number of flakes, all of Edwards Plateau chert, have been recovered among the bone piles. The assignment of FA6-8 to the Folsom occupation is based principally on stratigraphic and radiocarbon associations. The feature is located in the lowest major organic lamination of the diatomite. A date of 10,880 + 85 years B.P. (SMU 292) was obtained on snails from the Area 6 basal diatomite that immediately underlies the organic layer in which FA6-8 is located. The other date of 10,531 + 86 years B.P. (SMU 285) is on humates from the lowest diatomite member in Area 2 on the northeast side of the site. A date of 10,063 + 74 years B.P. (SMU 251) was secured from an organic zone within the diatomite in Area 3 on the east side of the site. Area

FIGREF3.text: The late Plaeoindian horizon is a general cultural period comprised of several culture complexes such as Cody, Firstview, andFrederick. These complexes are best known from the central and northern Plains of the United States and Canada. This horizon, also known as the Piano, spans the time from the end of Folsom to the end of the Paleoindian period: ca, 10,000 to 8,000 years ago. Late Paleoindian cultures are identified by a variety of generally lanceolate, unfluted, well-made projectile points that include such types as Eden, Scottsbluff, Plainview, Firstview, Milnesand, and

FIGREF4.text: ) is quite similar to the point in question. This artifact, then, is tentatively considered to be of the Firstview type.The point recovered by Fig 9, k)  has been heavily reworked along all edges. The remaining original flake scars reflect good workmanship, although not the high quality transverse and colateral flaking seen on some specimens of this period. The relationship of the flaking and thickness to the projected width, usingWheat's (1972:148-149)  indices of projectile point relative thickness, indicates an artifact along the lines of Firstview.Howevery since the original shape is unknown, some of the nonparallel sided varieties such as Agate Basin and Milnesand should also be considered.As noted above, portions of three late Paleoindian projectile points have been found in situ by the Lubbock Lake Project, as well as a redeposited, possible late Paleoindian projectile point. Artifact TTU-A7563 (Fig. 9, g) is apparently the midsection of a point, made from a chert of unknown source. This specimen is from FA6-5, a camping locality situated stratigraphically at the contact of substrata 2B/2C. The item is straight sided and lenticular in cross section, approaching a medial ridge. Flaking is irregular collateral As with the point recovered byGreen (1962), a definite assignment to a typological category is impossible since the overall dimensions and morphology are unknown. However, the relative-thickness, the flaking, and the parallel sides are typological indicators. Some variety of the Firstview complex(Wheat, 1972)  appears to be the best possibility.Artifact TTU-A19285(Fig. 9, j)is apparently the base of a projectile point. This item was also found in FA6-5. The material is a Tecovas quartzite. The relatively poor quality of this material probably contributed to the shape of the artifact. The specimen has parallel sides, a slightly concave base, and both lateral and basal grinding. In cross section, this artifact appears to be bev-eled along the right edge. Flake scars are difficult to see due to the nature of the material. This item may have been broken during manufacturing, and represents an unfinished point (H. M. Wormington, personal communication). It also exhibits some reworking along the edges and may have been used as a butchering tool.Artifact TTU-18464 (Fig. 9, i)is the midsection and distal end of a projectile point. This item comes from FA6-11, a bison kill/ butchering locale in the cienega zone at the base of substratum 2B, just above the 2A contact in Area 6. The specimen seems to be parallel sided, although one edge and possibly the other has certainly been reworked. Some evidence of lateral grinding remains just above the break. The point is lenticular in cross section and relatively thin. Flaking is irregular parallel. Although the base is missing, the observable characteristics fall within the range of the Plainview type (R. Knudson and J. B. I^eat, personal communication). The reworked side of the artifact exhibits a serrated edge similar to

FIGREF5.text: Fig. 5) during initial testing of this excavation area. In this area, substratum 5C unconformably overlies stratum 2. The tip and one corner of the base are missing. The characteristics of this point are diagnostic of Paleoindian projectile points. The edges are constricted just above the base; then, they expand to the widest point, apparently about two-thirds of the length to the tip. The base is concave, with both lateral and basal grinding. The point has many of the attributes of the Agate Basin type, except for the expanding stem

FIGREF6.text: only on a typological basis. Associations with specific cultures or stratigraphic horizons are impossible, but these artifacts give some suggestions of the presence of certain cultural complexes. Two of the surface finds are almost certainly from the late Paleoindian period. The "Yuma" point (TMM 892-1,Fig. 8, a), one of the original surface discoveries in 1938, is a broken and apparently reworked mid-section. The original point has been lost. The plaster cast is of poor quality and flat on one side, presumably to aid in mounting it for display purposes. However, a good set of drawings and a photograph are on file at TARL. The specimen is parallel sided with some indication of a shoulder, possibly produced by heavylateral grinding. The collateral flaking is very good, giving the point a pronounced medial ridge. The cast displays a relatively thick cross section, almost half as thick as the item is wide. Because of the collateral flaking and thick cross section with pronounced medial ridge, the Eden variety of projectile points would be the most likely typological category. Two surface finds from this cultural period were made during the work of the Texas Memorial Museum. Figure 9, n illustrates a virtually complete projectile point lacking only the base. The l-,^ X artifact (TMM 892-85) has strongly convex sides widest at about > (/I the middle of the point. The stem exhibits heavy lateral grinding. _^ Flaking is relatively crude. Because of these features, this artifact could fall within the range of the Agate Basin type. The remaining surface find (TMM 892-73), (Fig. 9, ra) is difficult to classify. The base is broken and one side and the distal end have been reworked. The other side is slightly concave and exhibits some } lateral grinding towards the bottom. The specimen is lenticular in cross section and relatively thick. The slight concavity alongthe one side suggests a Plainview variety that is constricted just above the base then expands to about the mid section(Sellards, et al., 1947:960, Plate 5,Fig. 1). However, the relative thickness of this artifact is not typical of the Plainview variety in general.The three projectile points recovered by the Lubbock Lake Project come from the same excavation area (Area 6) and the exact strati-graphic relationships are known. These items, then, provide the best information on late Paleoindian cultural sequences at the site. The broken Plainview point was found in the base of substratum 2B just above the 2A contact, and the mid-section and base were found in the n n "S same feature at the top of substratum 2B at about the 2B/2C contact. There are some stratigraphic problems associated with the only other late Paleoindian projectile point recovered i^ situ, the Firstview point (TMM 892-69) found in 1949. This specimen, from station A just west of Area 9 (Figs. 2, 5), was found "in Bed No. 2, 4" to 7" above top of Bed No. 1. At this location. Bed No. 2 consists mainly of dark gray, carbonaceous and probably diatomaceous sand, a marginal valley facies of the diatomite member. The point was 3 feet, 4 inches below the base of Bed No. 5, the 'muck layer'"

FIGREF7.text: All of the above information suggests, at least on typological grounds, the presence of Plainview and Firstview occupations. Surface finds indicate the possibility of Eden and Agate Basin occupations. A radiocarbon determination, indirectly associated with the Plainview occupation, falls into the upper range of this cultural period

FIGREF8.text: range of dates for Firstview points. A possible explanation may be the nature of substratum*2C. This deposit represents a standing marsh that may have existed for some time. Younger humates from near the end of the life of the marsh mixed with older humates from its formation may give an average of the age of substratum 2C rather than an absolute range. Radiocarbon dates from substratum 2B rather than 2C are needed to clarify this problem. The Plainview point was associated with a bison kill/butchering locale. The bison remains were grouped, although not actually stacked. This feature represents the only remains of cultural activity directly associated with the Plainview occupation, to date. In excavation Area 9, another bison kill/butchering locale was uncovered. This feature may also be associated with the Plainview occupation. The locale is at the base of substratum 2E. If this substratum is indeed, directly correlateable to substratum 2B, the feature may correlate with the one in Area 6. However, the precise relationship of substrata 2E to 2B has not yet been determined. Besides the bison kills, no other Plainview activity areas are known at the site. FIGREF9.text: The two in situ projectile point fragments with possible Firstview affiliations(TTU-A7563 and 19285)  are associated with what was apparently part of a camp. The feature (FA6-5) is an extensive accumulation of lithic debris. Over 150 lithic items have been recovered ±n situ with approximately 75% of the artifacts exhibiting some sort of use(Figs. 12, 13). A variety of small animal remains and clusters of bison bones were also recovered. The small animal remains and the great amount of lithic debris would suggest a camping area. The bison bones that have been butchered suggest a small kill, perhaps during a period when the area was not being used as a camp. The exact relationship of the bison remains to the camping debris has yet to bedetermined. A Tecovas quartzite knife (TTU-A13401, Fig. 10, b) with strongly beveled sides was recovered in FA6-5. Two additional artifacts with beveled blades (TTU-A18759 and 3049, Figs. 10, c, d) were found in other excavation areas within the upper portion of substratum 2B. In addition, during the work of the Texas Memorial Museum, an artifact (TMM 892-75, Fig. 10, a) was recovered that is similar, in some respects, to the artifact from FA6-5. Basically, none of the tools strongly resemble each other, but the presence of beveled H blades on all of them suggests a preference for beveled blades during ^ the late Paleoindian period. ^•'' The basic cultural associations for the late Paleoindian at the i Lubbock Lake site thus far indicated would include a Plainview and Firstview occupation. Wheat's (1972:154-158) Firstview complex includes both Firstview and Plainview points as well as Milnesand, and ; seem to be concentrated in the central and southern Plains. The I Plainview occupation is considered to be at the early part of the range in time occupied by the Firstview complex with Firstview points themselves continuing to about 9,000 years B.P. However, at the Lubbock Lake site, the two possible Firstview complex projectile point fragments are associated with radiocarbon dates of about 8,000 years B.P. Additional radiocarbon determinations and good associations with diagnostic artifact types are needed to clarify the problem. A Firstview occupation is certianly well demonstrated by the point recovered in 1949 during the work of the Texas Memorial Museum. Unfortunately, however, the exact stratigraphic provenience of this artifact is in question and the relationship of the stratigraphy in the area to the rest of the site is not yet certain. The surface finds of the Texas Memorial Museum also suggest the presence of an Agate Basin occupation and a Cody complex occupation (evidenced by a possible Eden point fragment). Although Agate Basin occupations are common throughout the Plains, the Cody complex has been considered a northern Plains tradition contemporaneous with the Firstview complex. The Cody complex, however, is not restricted to the northern Plains and some evidence of the presence of this culture

FA8-7 is an accumulation of small retouch flakes. The other two hearths were found outside of the basinal portion of the site. In area 15 (Fig. 5), just south of the main work area, a pit originating in the 5A sands but cutting into the 4C soil was found during the course of machine testing operations. The pit -H rn contained hearth debris. A Garza type projectile point (TTU-A3320, X Fig. 11, f), some lithic flakes, and broken bison bones were asso-1X1 ciated with the pit. A radiocarbon determination of A.D. 1665 + 60 (S.I. 2703) was secured from the hearth debris. To the north of the site, in Area 14 (Fig. 5), a hearth was located during the course of archaeological monitoring of pipeline construction by Pioneer Natural Gas Company. Another Garza point (TTU-A3283, Fig. 11, h) and a number of lithic flakes were found around and within the hearth (Johnson, 1975:4). Charcoal from the hearth yielded a date of A.D. 1635 + 50 (S.I. 2704). The stratigraphic position of this hearth is not certain but it is probably from the 5A sands. Two small Contact period features have been investigated in Area 4 (FA4-2 and FA4-3). FA4-2 consisted of some scattered, butchered bison remains and several stone tools including a Lott point (TTU-A2122,Fig. 11, c). FA4-3 is stratigraphically below FA4-2.This feature consisted of a shallow, unlined, basin-shaped hearth with a few associated lithic items and some bone. A radiocarbon date on charcoal from the hearth was "modern" (S.I. 2702). The hearth had been exposed in an erosional channel for some time before it was excavated and the charcoal may have been contaminated. The -I assessment of an Historic age for both features is based on the geology. On the southwestern side of the site, including Area 4, a small, filled, erosional channel has been observed. This channel is at least post-5A in age since it cuts through substratum 5A.Both FA4-2 and FA4-3 are within this channel fill and therefore of post-5A age, placing them in the Historic period.The remaining Contact period features are FA5-1 and FA5-6. Tnese periods have been established principally on the basis of I associations with diagnostic artifacts (primarily projectile points) I and radiocarbon determinations, and by comparing both artifacts and I dates with neighboring areas for which chronological information is available. --For each of the four periods, certain problems can be identified and each of the problems provides the basis for future investigations. In the Paleoindian period, the cultural associations of the late Paleoindian features are still uncertain. The material thus far recovered indicates some possible associations but only additional work and especially the recovery of additional artifacts will clarify and identify these associations. The same problem, although to a lesser degree, exists within the Clovis period. Again, association of diagnostic material with the mammoth processing station would clarify the situation. The Archaic period probably presents the single greatest problem in the cultural chronology. So little is known that it is difficult to even indicate specific directions for future work.

FIGREF19.text: tity. A specific problem is the determination of the relationship of Puebloan ceramics to an otherwise Plains occupation situation. The Historic period presents some intriguing problems concerning the identification of the historic occupants of the area. A number of features have already been identified for this period. The unique situation of having a well-stratified and dated sequence of late Ceramic, contact and late Historic features provides an opportunity to study the Historic period in detail. A careful study of the archaeological information combined with ethnohistorical investigations ;"' may make it possible to identify the presence of specific historic ^^ aboriginal groups in the area and perhaps trace their movements into -| and out of the region. In addition to the problems within each time period, there are j •'••« several general areas of investigation that would help in clarifying the overall cultural chronology for the area. Additional radiocarbon assays are mandatory in order to establish a more detailed temporal framework for both archaeological and geological purposes. Additional paleoenvironmental data for all periods would provide information on the nature of the area at specific times, and identify environmental changes that may affect existing populations. An important specific investigation along these lines would be the determination of the nature and age of various soil forming intervals. The stratigraphic manifestations of these intervals, principally the A horizons, are more likely to contain evidence of human occupation because of their stability. An important problem, then, would be the presence of im x: occupational debris within a stratigraphic unit that represented a long period of time. There are a number of major problems yet to be solved at the Lubbock Lake site, many of which are being pursued by the present investigators. The potential exists to solve others through future research. The cultural chronology presented herein provides a framework within which to conduct these future investigations. Although the chronology is certain to change as a result of additional work, it provides a basis on which to build the first detailed record of the past 12,000 years in the Lubbock area. This chronology, in turn, forms the basis on which to build a needed regional cultural chronology for the Llano Estacado. Once a regional chronology is established, it will then be possible to study culture process on the Southern High Plains and the nature and effect of the environment on this process. FIGREF25.text: sources take the form of both outcrops and gravel deposits. The former are generally located some distance from Lubbock (at least 50 miles and generally more) but do provide good materials. The gravel deposits, of Pleistocene age, were probably common in the area before Holocene deposition began filling the drainage ways.Within these gravels a variety of materials were available, though apparently in limited quantity (Charles A. Johnson II, personal communication). The most common material found is a medium to fine grained chert from the Edwards formation of the Cretaceous. This chert ranges in color from a light gray to dark blue-gray as well as a medium to dark caramel brown, sometimes referred to as "jasper". For flint working this material is generally good to excellent. This chert is quite common in Central Texas owing to the many exposures of the Edwards formation limestone and because of the relative abundance of the chert in the limestone. In the Lubbock area, though, there are no such exposures. As far as is known the nearest exposure of "typical" Edwards chert is near San Angelo, Texas in Tom Green County (James A. Word, personal communication), about 200 miles southeast of Lubbock. However there are some Cretaceous outcrops nearer to Lubbock that do produce some chert though generally not as fine a quality as the Central Texas material. These are near Fluvanna, Texas in Scurry County and Gail, Texas in Borden County (John P. Brand, personal communication), approximately 70 miles southeast and south-southeast of Lubbock respectively.

TABREF0.text: 41LU1) is an important archaeological, geological, and paleontological locality situated in a meander bend of Yellowhouse Draw in north Lubbock County, Texas (33°37'13.5"N latitude, 101°53'31.5"W longitude) (Fig. 1). The locality is on the Llano Estacado, or southern High Plains of Texas. An essentially flat, extensive plateau, the region is dissected by a number of northwest-southeast trending draws of which Yellowhouse Draw is one of the major ones. It now heads in Cochran and Hockley counties, Texas; although in earlier times it may have headed south of Clovis, New Mexico. Yellowhouse Draw joins with Blackwater Draw (several miles downstream from the Lubbock Lake site) in central Lubbock County, becoming Yellowhouse Canyon. The Double Mountain Fork of the Brazos River flows through the canyon.

of FA8-1, all of the features are from substratum 5C, the lowland

Other colors include oranges, dark yellows, and browns. Besides the ten banded.
chert, a Tecovas quartzite is also found and generally comes in the
same colors as the chert. This material is usually rather coarse
and although some tools are made of it, this quartzite would seem to
make poor working material. Another chert that is found at the Lub-
bock Lake site is the Potter variety. This material is a medium to
fine-grained chert and is usually a dull gray-green in color. This
chert is from the Pliocene Ogallala formation although specific out-
crops are not known. A quartzite, similar in color to Potter chert,
is also common and this, too, may be from the Potter formation (John
P. Brand, personal communication; Willey and Hughes, 19 75:1,475).
Tools made of other types of quartzite have also been recovered.
Morrison quartzite, from the Jurassic age Morrison formation, is
relatively common. This is a coarse quartzite, generally a distinc-
tive deep purple or red in color. No known outcrops occur on the
Southern Plains. The most likely source would be gravel deposits
(Charles A. Johnson, personal communication).
A material quite common to the Lubbock Lake site, though as far
as is known is not very common elsewhere, is silicified caliche.
This material is not of high quality as far as knapping is con-
TABREF20.text: Other varieties of chert found at the Lubbock Lake site include Alibates, Tecovas, and Potter. The well-known Alibates quarry in Potter county is about 150 miles north of Lubbock. This Permian outcrop produces a fine multi-colored chert found in archeological sites throughout the Great Plains. The chert is generally banded with the most common colors being reds, grays, and blues although yellows are Presumably due to the abundance of caliche in the area, however, the material is commonly found.
